application.name: slpmap
application.brief: Creates cubes that have slope data or aspect data
application.description:
This program will compute the slope or aspect of a cube. Typically a digital terrian model is given as the input but other non-elevation datasets can be provided. Horne's algorithm is used to compute the slope/aspect. That is, given a 3x3 kernel: A B C D E F G H I it is convolved through the image and each output pixel is computed as follows:
SLOPE EQUATION [dz/dx] = ((C + 2F + I) - (A + 2D + G)) / (8 * X_PIXEL_RESOLUTION) [dz/dy] = ((G + 2H + I) - (A + 2B + C)) / (8 * Y_PIXEL_RESOLUTION)
slope = ATAN ( SQRT ( [dz/dx]^2 + [dz/dy]^2 ) ) percentslope = slope / 90
ASPECT EQUATION [dz/dx] = ((C + 2F + I) - (A + 2D + G)) / 8 [dz/dy] = ((G + 2H + I) - (A + 2B + C)) / 8
aspect = 90 - ATAN2 ([dz/dy], -[dz/dx]) if (aspect < 0) then aspect = aspect + 360
Therefore slope is typically a number betwen 0 and 90 degrees which is flat to vertical slope, respectively. The aspect represents the direction (0 to 360) of the slope in pixel space. From the center pixel E, 0 degrees is straight towards B, 45 towards C, 90 is towards F, 135 towards I, 180 towards H, and so on. The user has the opportunity to output the slope in radians, degrees, or percent slope. The aspect can be in degrees or radians.
The above slope equation assume the pixels are not square; hence X_PIXEL_RESOLUTION and Y_PIXEL_RESOLUTION. That is, the x distance across the pixel is not equal to the y distance from top to the bottom of the pixel. By default the program will attempt to remove any scaling difference by using the map projection information (PIXRES=AUTOMATIC). This computation is done at every pixel so that the correct x-to-y ratio is computed. This is important for global maps where the ratio deviates as you move away from the latitude and/or longitude of true scale in the map projection. If the image lacks a map projection then the user must provide the pixel resolution, assumed to be square via PIXRES=USER. The user then provides a single value (RESOLUTION) that will be applied to all pixels in the image and in both directions.
The second assumption is that the xy units are the same as the z (pixel) units. By default the program assumes the units are the same but allows the user to scale the z units to the xy units using the CONVERSIONFACTOR parameter.

history.change: Changed the slope algorithm to compute the sample and line resolution at each pixel. Previously the algorithm used the resolution at the center of the image. In projected images the resolution varies as you move away from the latitude and/or longitude of true scale. Also, improved the documentation and added user options to output percent slope.

parameter.name: FROM
parameter.description: Use this parameter to select input cube. All bands of the cube within the file will have the algorithm applied.

parameter.name: TO
parameter.description: Use this parameter to define the filename of the resultant slope or aspect cube

parameter.name: OUTPUT
parameter.brief: Type of output requested, slope, aspect, or percent slope
parameter.description: This determines the type of output pixels that will be created. One of slope, aspect, or percent slope.

option.description: This creates an aspect cube. That is, the direction/azimuth of the slope.
This creates a slope cube whose pixel values are percentages (slope/90) instead of angles.
The output pixels will be in radians, between 0 and PI/2 for slope and 0 and 2PI for aspect.
The output pixels wiil be in degrees, between 0 and 90 for slope and 0 and 360 for aspect

parameter.name: CONVERSION
parameter.brief: Conversion from z units to spatial units
parameter.description:
Since the slope algorithm depends on cancelling out the units, the conversion factor from the z (input pixel) units to the xy (spatial) units needs to be considered.
For example, if the xy units are meters and the z units are in kilometers the unit conversion factor should be 1000 as we are converting z units to xy units.
The default is one which presumes the units are the same.

parameter.name: PIXRES
parameter.brief: Defines the pixel resolution (width and height)
parameter.description: This determines the how the resolution of the input pixels will be defined.

option.brief: Automatically compute the resolution using the map projection
option.description: The program will use the map projection to automatically compute the resolution (X and Y) of each pixel in order to ensure the slope is computed properly.

If the input cube does not have a map projection then this option can be used to define the resolution which is assumed to be square. A single resolution is used for the entire image in both the X and Y directions. Note: If the pixel height varies significantly from the width, the slope will not be computed correctly.

parameter.name: RESOLUTION
parameter.description: Defines both the X and Y pixel resolution to be used across the entire image. Note that if the pixel height varies significantly from the width, the slope will not be computed correctly.
